subject: QB for Trade
event:
So the other shoe has finally dropped in Denver, and it's now official: quarterback Jay Cutler is available for trade.  No big surprise.  Everybody but the Broncos has seemed to know that Cutler and Denver were done a month ago.

That decision to fire Mike Shanahan is looking worse and worse.

Big question from my end is whether the Jets should go after Cutler, now that he's officially on the market.  I admit to having mixed feelings about that.

With the NFL draft only a month away, all the draft gurus have been beating the drum about how the Jets need to draft a quarterback.  Myself, I think their collective analysis is faulty.  Right now the Jets have three QBs on the roster: Kellen Clemens, Brett Ratliffe, and Eric Ainge.  Between the three of them, they have a total of eight NFL starts.  That's why the draft gurus keep saying the Jets need a QB.  

But say the Jets listen, and draft Sanchez (if he falls to 17), or Freeman, or one of the other college QBs.  Now they will have four quarterbacks on the roster, and between they will still have a total of eight NFL starts.  So what's changed?  Clemens, Ratliffe, and Ainge are all young, raw talents with big arms and zero experience.  Any college kid the Jets can draft is going to be exactly the same.  There's no guarantee that Sanchez or Freeman is going to be any better over a career than Clemens, Ratliffe, or Ainge.  

So I've been against this draft-a-QB drumbeat.  The Jets need more help on defense, is what they need.  A big wide receiver to take the place of Laveranues Coles would also be good.

Cutler is a different proposition, however.  This is no raw recruit coming out of college, this is an established NFL quarterback, one that many commentators are saying is the best of his draft class.  He could be "Broadway Jay," I suppose, and lead the Jets for the next decades.  He has a big arm too, and that's an important asset in the windy Meadowlands.

But -- and here's where the doubts creep in -- he's also shown himself to be temperamental and thin-skinned.  That's the part that worries me.  If his feelings could be so badly bruised by his new coach's attempt to trade him, what's going to happen if he comes to New York and has a bad game, and the NYC media start in on him?  

I don't know.  I just don't know.

But it should be interesting to see how it all works out.

comments.article: I noticed his arm last season and I was really impressed. He did seem to make many mistakes, but it may have been due to the system he was in. If the Jets can create a "nurturing" environment, it may be worth it to pick him up. If not, I can see him becoming Ryan Leaf (attitude wise-not skill wise).

comments.upictitle: Brother Flaming Shuriken of Acceptance: Dangerous Thoughts (Iconomicon)
comments.article: As a Broncos fan, there have been plenty of reasons for me to look forward to the start of baseball season since, oh, about week 15 of the 2008 season.

For the Jets, I think he's worth the gamble. But then what do you give up for him? Certainly, the first round pick will have to be packaged, but what else does it cost to get Cutler? I'd say take the best of your QB prospects and he would also have to be in the package or you'd need to work a three way trade somehow where Denver gets at least a solid QB.

As someone who lives in SoCal, I'd advise anyone to stay far, far away from Sanchez at least until the late first round (it won't happen). He has has a lot of upside, but he's had, basically, one big game that lived up to his hype so far. He's made a BAD decision to leave USC this year and could really use another year in that offense, in my opinion.

Much as I wish him well and hope he does well. As a USC fan, I think Sanchez left too early. I didn't see the Rosebowl, but he wasn't super impressive all year in the Pac 10. I was looking forward to seeing him step up and perform consistently at a top college level next season. Oh well.

if you're fine with having Jeff George Jr. on your team, then you should fully support trading for Cutler. million-dollar arm, 10 cent head.

myself, I'll be sad to see him leave the AFC West. watching the Cutler Face® every time we put a beating on him was priceless.

On a related note, related only because I happen to live in Denver, I was wondering if you ever reached any kind of satisfactory closure to your tussles with PayPal. Did you ever find a decent alternative, have you accepted it as a necessary evil, or is it all water under the bridge?

I straight out don't like PayPal and many of their policies, and it always makes me nervous dealing through them, but it seems like having any kind of affordable online store requires their services.

For the record, I like the Jets but they're not my top team. That said I always like to see them do well and if my team falls (a common theme the last 15 years) I champion their playoff push.

I really agree with the need for some fresh talent to plug some holes on the D from trades and free agency. Also GRRM that is a great assessment of Cutler coming to the Jets, I hadn't actually considered it but it would be a great move for Cutler and the Jets (assuming as you pointed out that he could toughen up against the critics). Still I feel sorry for any QB that plays in the Meadowlands, its a great stadium but the wind always messes with the passing oriented QB's and their stats... most never adjust. Also I don't think the Jets should pick up a WR in the early rounds of the draft because they have some hidden and growing talent farther down on the depth chart that needs to be explored (namely Stuckey, Smith, and Henry).

In the end, I'd rather see the Jets pick up Warner or Collins since they're both free agents this year, just to mentor the others. And for a Wide-out, have a look at one of the following; Shaun McDonald, TJ Houshmandzadeh, Baskett, Gaffney, Hall or even the TE Daniels since they're all available and would be solid fits in a Jets uni.

Of all the QB's in the league Cutler's game is the most like Favre's and would be a natural fit if the Jets want to continue in the same direction offensively.  Well, like Favre's game except that Cutler is still mobile and has the potential for a decade as a top flight QB ahead of him.  I'm not sure that would be the right way for the Jets to go or not. Its just that Cutler would give them the least amount of transition and the most experience of any of the options open to them if they could land him.

I was hoping the raiders would draft him when he came out of college...

Didn't happen and when he started for denver that year i was really wishing they had.

though we have more problems than just a quarter back (like an O line that will give any decent QB the time to throw the ball)

I agree with you wholeheartedly.  I watched J.J. Harrington shrivel and die after being drafted 3rd a few yrs back by my perfect season lions.  Hey 0-16 is a sure perfect season!  But, then we have the kid from atlanta bailing them out of a dogfighting hole this year.(thank you mr. vick and may you never play again - although I'm sure the 'boys are drooling).  I would not put my 1st rounder on any QBs this year.  D-fense wins the game as many a G-men posts you have written have confirmed.  Draft a lineman, O or D.  Hey mario williams had a good year, better than reggie bush.  And where were the boys without Demarcus Ware - no pun intended, maybe.  With the no 1 pick?  I hope the lions trade for some goodies - and maybe I'd say cutler.  We'd crown him king for a day and with calvin godzilla johnson maybe bring some life into motown.
comments.subject: Culter for sale!

comments.article: Good take on the qb situation. I think Cutler just needs someone to sit him down and make him understand that he works for the team owner. Its that simple, he is their very well paid employee. This deal with Denver was started with sloppy management that caused distrust on both sides, and then Cutler making statements that showed him to be tempermental or thin skinned. Cutler seems young and intelligent, my guess is he gets a great lesson out of this and gets a shot at starting somewhere like the Jets.

The problem is that the Broncos are going to extract a high, high price for jay Cutler. I'm not sure your Jets want to give up their 1st round pick 2 years in a row for him. That's probably the minimum  he's going to go for. You're better off trying to pry Derek Anderson or Brady Quinn from the Browns.
comments.subject: Hmm

comments.article: Personally, I'd like to see the Jets focus on defense in the draft or via trade. They've got some support for a new QB with a good line and the dual threat of Thomas Jones and Leon Washington (who I suspect is going to have a breakout year).

Someone with a skin that thin is going to suffer in any media market now, especially NYC. Come on, Jay, this is a business and every single player is always on the trading block. If some team were to go to Indy and offer their first, second and third round picks every year for the next eight years for Peyton Manning, do you think he'd still be a Colt ten minutes later?

Now, obviously, players can and should be valued, but head coaches should say things just like McDaniel recently said. "Jay is our quarterback and we are committed to him, AND we are committed to improving this team by whatever means are available to us."

It's a shame, but Cutler has significantly affected his career with these antics. If you're going to force your way out of town with a power play, it helps to have had more success than a roughly .500 win percentage and no playoff victories.
I think Washington is going to throw a ton of money at both Cutler and Shanahan. Eventually, we'll buy a good enough team win the Super Bowl.

I think Detroit or the NYJ are the most likely landing spots for Cutler, with the Browns being involved somehow. Being impartial (Go Falcons!) I'd rather see him go to the Jets, the Lions being the Lions and all.

I'd like to see Cutler play with a competent defense, which the Jets had last year (at least for MOST of the season), and a running game.

The Broncos' defensive struggles and running back injuries really put a lot on Cutler's shoulders last year. The Jets are an upgrade on both accounts and I'd be excited to watch Cutler possibly develop into a superstar. I have family that went to Vandy so I've been following him for a while now.

As for New York media etc. I think he'll be fine. I think a large part of the his issue was that his mentor, Shanahan, was fired without his knowledge and then you have a 32 year old coach trying to trade you for Matt Cassell and then not being totally truthful about it. I know Cutler could have acted a bit more like an adult but I'm inclined to take his side.

Plus he's arrogant enough not to be bothered by fans and media, which can be a good thing for a QB.

PS - I'm not worried about Dragons, I haven't even read Crows yet so I've got time.

And I'd like to promote "Evil Robot Monkey" by Mary Robinette Kowal for the Hugo for Short Story, if that's allowed.
As long as he doesn't end up in the NFC east or on the Vikings...He'll probably end up in Cleveland or Detroit.
comments.subject: Cutler

comments.article: Jets should go after Cutler hard.  They have many more problems than QB.  Get him and then focus on their other issues.  Cutler is too good and too young to let get away.

I have followed Cutler pretty closely the last couple of years (he's my fantasy QB in a keeper league with fairly high stakes) and I believe he would be the kind of player that could take a good team far into the playoffs. He almost got a Denver team there with what was possibly the worst defense ever assembled.
The Jets have a solid team and could benefit from getting a good young proven QB(and getting Thomas Jones happy and in the fold).
As far as Cutlers thin skin; that could be problematic but I can't attribute the entire swirl in Denver to Cutler and Cutler alone. From what is being reported, his problem with the whole thing is that McDaniels told him that they were just listening to offers while Cutlers agent was telling him he was being told by people in the know that McDaniel was the one dangling trade offers.
Once trust is gone in any kind of relationship, it is hard to rebuild, and in this case, maybe broken for good.
I am a lifetime Cowboy fan (I know, I know; boo, hiss) and I just don't want to see Cutler traded to any of the NFC East teams. Take that for what it's worth.
I'm not sure that Cutler has it in him, to be a mentor to a younger QB. Still, I could be wrong.

Cutler may be talented, but he strikes me as petulant.  He's never won anything - didn't even have a winning season in college - and yet he's such a diva that he can basically tell an NFL owner to pound sand because he felt slighted.  I dunno, maybe time will prove me wrong, and i'm sure there are 2 sides to the story, but if I was an NFL owner I'd probably steer well clear of him.

Honestly, Cutler has worked himself out of Denver. If anything Mike Shannahan coddled him way too much and put him above the team. For McDaniels to work, it's gotta be his guy now. But the guy I blame is Bus Cook - also Favre's agent for the past two seasons. And look at how that worked out.

That being said, any team that finally decides to acquire him is getting a leader, an absolute cannon, and an impressive teammate.

On a side note...what's with the Patriots assisstants fucking up as many franchises as they can? Maginini, Romeo, Weis at Notre Dame, etc...maybe it's a conspiracy. At least the next month is going to be really, really interesting.

I'd like to see him come to the Bears but we have nothing to offer in trade.

On second thought, Denver can have Hester straight up for Cutler. I could live with that trade.

From what I understand, the Vikings may be the front-runners for Cutler. Besides, I think he'd be a bust in NY for the reasons you stated. I'm hoping the Seahawks aren't serious about drafting Sanchez at #4...they have a fine QB in Hasselbeck (even if I can't stand his wife) and a decent back-up in Seneca Wallace. They need help on both sides of the line before they even entertain drafting a QB. Plus, there's still that aging receiving corps; the addition of Houshmandzedeh nonwithstanding. Seattle also needs a running game so Hasselbeck stays off the turf.
You could be a Browns fan.
comments.subject: Take heart.
